item.title: qiskit-ibm-transpiler Ranks #3 in Unitary Foundation 2025 Survey
item.description:
üöÄ üöÄüöÄ Climbing the ranks in quantum software!

I’m thrilled to share that the qiskit-ibm-transpiler library has moved up to #3 in the Unitary Foundation 2025 Survey under Full-stack development platforms, compilers, and simulators. Just last year, we were #4 ‚Äî and this year‚Äôs leap is a testament to the incredible work of the team behind it.

In less than two years, the package has surpassed 929K downloads, becoming a relevant tool for quantum circuit optimization/transpilation across the community.

One of the most exciting updates this year: our AI transpiler passes ‚Äî including the latest Pauli Networks pass ( arXiv:2503.14448) ‚Äî can now run in local mode, removing the need for an IBM Quantum premium plan. This makes advanced AI-powered transpilation more accessible than ever.

The Unitary Fund survey is widely recognized as the primary pulse check for quantum software adoption and developer preferences. Seeing our work reflected there is both humbling and energizing.

Huge kudos to the amazing team behind this David Kremer, V√≠ctor Villar Pascual, Jes√∫s Talavera G√≥mez, Yaiza Garc√≠a Mart√≠n-Mantero, Ismael Faro ‚Äî your dedication, creativity, and deep technical insight are what make this possible. And thank you to the community for your continued trust and feedback.

Let‚Äôs keep pushing the boundaries of quantum + AI software together.

#QuantumComputing #Qiskit #IBMQuantum #AITranspiler #UnitaryFund #QuantumSoftware #OpenSource #AIforQuantum

Originally shared on LinkedIn on November 10, 2025 - 50 reactions as of 11/11/2025

item.title: AI for Qiskit. Hackathon starter pack
Quantum Processing Unit (QPU) processing time Prediction with Machine Learning
David Peral Garc√≠a Successfully Defends His PhD Thesis on Quantum NLP
item.description:
üéì Last Friday was a very special day - David Peral Garc√≠a successfully defended his PhD thesis!

This milestone holds special significance for me as my first doctoral thesis as an advisor, and I couldn’t be prouder of David’s groundbreaking work.

His research on Quantum Natural Language Processing represents what is likely the first PhD thesis in Spain dedicated to this emerging field, positioning him among the pioneers shaping the future of quantum computing and NLP.

David’s contributions have already made a substantial impact in the research community, with notable publications including:

üìÑ A comprehensive survey on Quantum NLP in Computer Science Review: https://doi.org/10.1016/j.cosrev.2024.100619

üìÑ Novel applications in Expert Systems with Applications: https://doi.org/10.1016/j.eswa.2024.124427

And there are more exciting contributions on the way that will further advance this fascinating intersection of quantum computing and language processing.

My deepest gratitude to the evaluation committee Mario Piattini, Anupama Ray, and Roberto Theron for their time, expertise, and valuable feedback, and to the co-advisor Francisco Jos√© Garc√≠a-Pe√±alvo for their essential collaboration throughout this journey.

Congratulations, Dr. Peral-Garc√≠a! üéâ

The future of Quantum NLP looks brighter with innovators like you leading the way.

#PhD #QuantumComputing #NLP #Research #QuantumNLP #AcademicMilestone

Originally shared on LinkedIn on September 29, 2025 - 121 reactions, 14 comments as of 11/12/2025

item.title: Keynote Speaker at Metafuturo 2025: Quantum Computing + AI Convergence
item.description:
üöÄ Thrilled to have been part of Metafuturo 2025 as a keynote speaker!

I had the incredible opportunity to share insights on the convergence of Quantum Computing + AI at this forward-thinking event organized by Bizkaiko Foru Aldundia / Diputaci√≥n Foral de Bizkaia and ATRESMEDIA.

The intersection of quantum technologies and artificial intelligence represents one of the most exciting frontiers in tech today. During my talk, I shared what we are doing in this field at IBM Quantum. From LLMs and agentic AI applications for quantum computing to AI-optimized quantum circuits, we’re witnessing the birth of computational capabilities that seemed like science fiction just a few years ago.

What struck me most during the event was the genuine curiosity and engagement from attendees across diverse industries. The talks and panels ranged from practical implementations to philosophical implications‚Äîexactly the kind of multidisciplinary dialogue we need as we navigate this quantum journey.

Huge thanks to the organizers for creating such a vibrant platform for discussing the technologies that will shape our tomorrow. Events like Metafuturo 2025 are essential for building bridges between cutting-edge research and real-world applications.

The future is quantum-enhanced, AI-powered, and closer than we think! üî¨‚ö°

#QuantumComputing #ArtificialIntelligence #Innovation #Metafuturo2025 #TechTrends #QuantumAI #FutureOfTech #IBM

item.title: AI Methods for Permutation Circuit Synthesis Across Generic Topologies
IEEE Quantum Week in Albuquerque: AI and Quantum Computing at IBM Quantum
item.description:
üöÄ Excited to be attending IEEE Quantum Week in Albuquerque, New Mexico! I’ll be sharing some of the work we’re doing at IBM Quantum, especially at the intersection of AI and Quantum Computing. If you’re around and passionate about Quantum, AI, or both‚Äîlet’s connect! Here’s where you can find me:

üß† Today, Sunday, August 31 ‚Äì 4:00PM Paper Presentation: “Quantum Processing Unit (QPU) Processing Time Prediction with Machine Learning”. We’ll explore how ML can improve QPU time prediction for quantum jobs‚Äîenabling smarter quantum workload scheduling.

üõ†Ô∏è Monday, September 1 ‚Äì 10:00AM Tutorial: “TUT13 ‚Äî AI Methods for Quantum Circuit Optimization”. Together with David Kremer, we’ll demonstrate how Reinforcement Learning can be used to transpile and synthesize quantum circuits, using qiskit-ibm-transpiler and other tools developed by our team.

üí° Tuesday, September 2 ‚Äì 12:00PM Live Demo at IBM Quantum Booth #400. I’ll demo our new AI-powered quantum computing development environment‚Äîdesigned to bridge the gap between quantum theory and practical implementation in a visual way.

If you’re attending and want to talk about AI for Quantum, Quantum+AI, or our work at IBM Quantum‚Äîfeel free to reach out or stop by!

#IEEEQuantumWeek #IBMQuantum #QuantumComputing #AIforQuantum #QuantumPlusAI

item.title: Quantum Verifiable Rewards for Post-Training Qiskit Code Assistant
item.description:
üìÑ We just released a new paper “Quantum Verifiable Rewards for Post-Training Qiskit Code Assistant” - and it’s been getting great attention from folks in the quantum field since day one. üéâ

üîç What we built: A novel approach to train AI models that can write better quantum code using Qiskit. What makes this interesting:

‚úÖ Quantum verification at the core - Instead of just hoping the AI-generated code works, we actually verify it runs correctly on real quantum systems ‚úÖ Smart training pipeline - We created synthetic quantum problem-test pairs and used both Direct Preference Optimization (DPO) and Group Relative Policy Optimization (GRPO) to align our models ‚úÖ Real quantum feedback - Our models learn directly from quantum hardware and systems rewards, ensuring the code they generate actually works in practice

The results: Our best model significantly outperforms existing leading open-source baselines on the challenging Qiskit-HumanEval-hard benchmark.

This work presents a solid contribution to making quantum programming more accessible through AI assistance. The approach of using quantum hardware verification to train coding assistants opens up promising directions for future research.

Proud of our team’s thoughtful work on this project: Nicolas Dupuis, Adarsh Tiwari, Youssef MROUEH, David Kremer, Ismael Faro. The intersection of AI and quantum computing continues to offer compelling research opportunities.

Paper: https://arxiv.org/abs/2508.20907

#QuantumComputing #AI #MachineLearning #Qiskit #Research #AIforQuantum

Originally shared on LinkedIn on August 30, 2025 - 76 reactions, 0 comments as of 11/12/2025

item.title: AI Transpiler Passes Enable Quantum Volume Breakthrough on IBM Hardware
item.description:
üöÄ Great to see this progress on the quantum hardware side! üöÄ

I’m also really proud of our work on the AI transpiler passes that enabled this advancement in quantum volume. When I started working with David Kremer, Ivan Duran Martinez, Hanhee Paik and Ismael Faro on these AI-powered passes, we were motivated to push the limits of transpilation to deliver the best results to our clients.

It’s incredibly rewarding to see how our efforts are making real impact, like what Jay Gambetta has highlighted here.

Thanks to the entire team involved in the AI transpiler passes - V√≠ctor Villar Pascual, Jes√∫s Talavera G√≥mez, Yaiza Garc√≠a Mart√≠n-Mantero, Ayushi Dubal, Sanjay Vishwakarma, and many others - this kind of progress is only possible through all of our effort! üôåüôåüôå

Context In response to: Jay Gambetta’s post on quantum volume achievements celebrating IBM’s r3 beta QPU (ibm_pittsburgh) achieving quantum volume milestones of 1024 and 2048, utilizing AI-optimized transpilation circuits developed by our team.

item.description:

These new models bring enhanced capabilities and broader compatibility to quantum computing development.

What’s New:

‚ú® Qiskit 2.0 Compatibility - Our newer models are fully compatible with Qiskit 2.0 code, ensuring seamless development with the latest quantum computing framework

üß† Enhanced Text Understanding - Significant improvements in general text comprehension and code generation capabilities

üî¨ Expanding Our Horizons - We continue to leverage the newest stable versions of IBM Granite 3.2 and 3.3 models, while for the first time exploring beyond IBM Granite with the powerful Qwen2.5-Coder series

Available Models: ‚Ä¢ Granite 3.3 8B Qiskit (+ GGUF) ‚Ä¢ Granite 3.2 8B Qiskit (+ GGUF) ‚Ä¢ Qwen2.5-Coder 14B Qiskit (+ GGUF)

All models are available on Hugging Face and ready for local deployment!

item.title: Among IBM Giants and Pioneers: Reflections from IBM Tech 2025 in Singapore
item.description:
Among üëÅÔ∏èüêù‚ìÇÔ∏è Giants and Pioneers: Reflections from IBM Tech 2025 in Singapore üá∏üá¨

I had the privilege of attending IBM Tech 2025 in Singapore this week - an exclusive, invitation-only gathering of IBM’s top technical talent from around the world. As one of the selected participants, I’m humbled to have been recognized among IBM’s most innovative and performing technical minds.

The atmosphere was electric as we dove deep into the future of AI, quantum computing, and emerging technologies. What struck me most was not just the cutting-edge content of the presentations from colleagues and leaders such as Ruchir Puri, Suja Viswesan, Ric Lewis, Borja Peropadre, and others, but the quality of conversations happening between sessions. Exchanging ideas with brilliant colleagues across different technical disciplines provided invaluable perspective on where technology is headed.

Particularly enlightening were the discussions with my IBM Quantum and AI Research colleagues and the cross-pollination of ideas between different technical domains. These connections reinforced my belief that the most transformative innovations happen at the intersection of diverse expertise.

Beyond the technical exchanges, Singapore provided a stunning backdrop for cultural experiences that complemented our professional activities. The city’s blend of tradition and futuristic vision perfectly mirrored our discussions about building tomorrow’s technologies while honoring established principles.

Returning home energized and inspired, I’m grateful for both the recognition and the opportunity to contribute to IBM’s technical community. The future belongs to those who collaborate across boundaries, and IBM Tech 2025 demonstrated that our collective expertise is our greatest strength.

#IBMTech2025 #Innovation #TechnicalExcellence #QuantumComputing #AI #FutureTech #IBMLife #AIforQuantum

item.title: qiskit-ibm-transpiler Ranks #4 in Unitary Fund 2024 Survey
item.description:
üéâ Exciting news! The qiskit-ibm-transpiler has been recognized as the “4th most used quantum computing development tool globally” in the 2024 Unitary Fund survey under the “Full-stack development platforms, compilers, and simulators” category.

What makes this particularly remarkable? The project has only been publicly available for just over a year!

üîç What is the qiskit-ibm-transpiler?

It’s a library that combines Qiskit’s powerful heuristic algorithms with our cutting-edge AI transpiler passes. Think of it as a sophisticated translator that optimizes your quantum code to run more efficiently on real quantum hardware.

üåç What this means:

This recognition reflects both the growing adoption of quantum computing and the community’s trust in AI-powered tools. It’s an acknowledgment of not just our technology, but of every developer who has contributed to and embraced this project.

üîó Resources:

  • GitHub: https://github.com/Qiskit/qiskit-ibm-transpiler
  • Documentation: https://docs.quantum.ibm.com/transpile/qiskit-ibm-transpiler

Thank you to everyone who has been part of this journey. Here’s to pushing the boundaries of quantum computing together! üöÄ

#QuantumComputing #OpenSource #Qiskit #IBM #SoftwareDevelopment #AITranspilerPasses #QiskitIBMTranspiler #AIforQuantum

item.title: AI methods for approximate compiling of unitaries
AI Methods for Approximate Compiling of Unitaries Paper Published
item.description:
Excited to share our latest research: “AI methods for approximate compiling of unitaries”! üöÄ

This work explores how artificial intelligence can make quantum circuit compilation more efficient. We focus on superconducting quantum hardware using fixed two-qubit gates and single-qubit rotations.

üîç Our approach:

  1. Three-stage process: identifying templates, predicting parameters, and refining through gradient descent
  2. Uses deep learning and autoencoder-like models to suggest initial templates and parameter values
  3. Demonstrates improvements over exhaustive search and random initialization on 2 and 3-qubit unitaries

This research highlights AI’s potential to enhance quantum circuit transpiling, supporting more efficient quantum computations on current and future hardware.

The paper has been accepted at QCE24 (Fifth IEEE International Conference on Quantum Computing and Engineering)!

Read the paper: https://arxiv.org/abs/2407.21225v1

Originally shared on LinkedIn on August 7, 2024 - 58 reactions, 0 comments as of 11/12/2025

item.title: Qiskit HumanEval: Evaluation Benchmark for Quantum Code Generation Published
item.description:
Excited to share our new research paper introducing the Qiskit HumanEval dataset! üöÄ

This work addresses a critical need: evaluating Large Language Models’ capability to generate quantum computing code. Our dataset comprises more than 100 quantum computing tasks, each with accompanying prompts, solutions, test cases, and difficulty ratings.

We systematically tested LLMs on their ability to produce executable quantum code, demonstrating the feasibility of using generative AI tools in quantum code development and establishing important benchmarks for the field.

This research opens new possibilities for AI-assisted quantum software development and provides a standardized way to measure progress in this exciting intersection of quantum computing and artificial intelligence.

Read the paper: https://arxiv.org/abs/2406.14712v1

#quantumcomputing #ibmquantum #qiskit #llms

Originally shared on LinkedIn on July 3, 2024 - 70 reactions, 7 comments as of 11/12/2025

item.title: Reinforcement Learning for Quantum Transpiling: Research Paper Published
item.description:
Excited to share research demonstrating the integration of Reinforcement Learning (RL) into quantum transpiling workflows for the Qiskit transpiler service! üöÄ

This work achieves near-optimal circuit synthesis and routing with significant performance improvements over traditional optimization methods like SAT solvers.

Key achievements: ‚úÖ Linear Function, Clifford, and Permutation circuit synthesis up to 65 qubits ‚úÖ Substantial reductions in two-qubit gate depth for routing up to 133 qubits ‚úÖ Performance advantages over SABRE routing heuristics ‚úÖ Practical efficiency for quantum transpiling pipelines

This research represents a major step forward in making quantum computing more efficient and accessible through AI-powered optimization.

Big thanks to the amazing team: David Kremer, V√≠ctor Villar Pascual, Hanhee Paik, Ivan Duran Martinez, and Ismael Faro!

Read the paper: https://lnkd.in/dcnw4Zav

#qiskit #quantumcomputing #IBMQuantum

Originally shared on LinkedIn on June 17, 2024 - 48 reactions, 0 comments as of 11/12/2025

item.title: Comparing Natural Language Processing and Quantum NLP: Research Published
item.description:
Excited to share our peer-reviewed publication “Comparing Natural Language Processing and Quantum Natural Processing approaches in text classification tasks”! üöÄ

This collaborative work with David Peral Garc√≠a and Francisco Jos√© Garc√≠a-Pe√±alvo has been published in Expert Systems with Applications.

Key findings:

  • ‚úÖ Quantum NLP models can obtain the same or better results in some datasets for simpler text classification tasks like entity recognition and sentiment analysis
  • ‚úÖ Performance diminishes with increased label complexity and sentence difficulty
  • ‚úÖ Experiments utilized up to 7 qubits and tested on both new and existing datasets across multiple classification scenarios

While the results are promising, we identified that advancing to larger-scale quantum applications requires more powerful quantum hardware and sophisticated software infrastructure.

This research contributes to our understanding of where quantum computing can provide advantages in natural language processing tasks and highlights the path forward for future developments.

Read the full paper on ScienceDirect. DOI

Originally shared on LinkedIn on June 17, 2024 - 19 reactions, 0 comments as of 11/12/2025

item.title: Comparing Natural Language Processing and Quantum Natural Processing approaches in text classification tasks
Practical and efficient quantum circuit synthesis and transpiling with Reinforcement Learning
Systematic Literature Review: Quantum Machine Learning and Its Applications Published
item.description:
Excited to share our systematic literature review paper “Systematic literature review: Quantum machine learning and its applications” published in Computer Science Review! üöÄ

This comprehensive work, in collaboration with David Peral Garc√≠a and Francisco Jos√© Garc√≠a-Pe√±alvo from the University of Salamanca, Spain, analyzes the state of quantum machine learning research from 2017 to 2023.

Key findings from our review of 94 studies:

  • ‚úÖ Identified two primary algorithm categories: quantum versions of classical ML algorithms (support vector machines, k-nearest neighbors) and quantum neural networks
  • ‚úÖ Image classification emerged as a particularly relevant application area
  • ‚úÖ While quantum machine learning demonstrates promise, it remains far from achieving its full potential

Our analysis highlights that quantum hardware improvements are necessary, as current quantum computers lack sufficient quality, speed, and scalability for QML’s full realization.

This research provides valuable insights into the current state and future directions of quantum machine learning.

Read the full paper: https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S1574013724000030. DOI

Originally shared on LinkedIn on February 5, 2024 - 53 reactions, 4 comments as of 11/12/2025

item.title: Systematic Literature Review: Quantum Machine Learning and its applications
IBM Quantum Summit 2023: Major Announcements on Quantum Utility
item.description:
I am thrilled and honored by the major announcements from IBM Quantum Summit 2023! üöÄ

Key highlights advancing quantum utility:

Hardware Breakthroughs:

  • IBM Heron chip: 3-5x device performance improvement over Eagle
  • IBM Condor: 1,121-processor system demonstrating scaling solutions
  • IBM Quantum System Two: Now operational at Yorktown Lab with 3 Heron processors

Software Innovations:

  • Qiskit 1.0: Scheduled February release with improvements in circuit construction, compilation times, and memory consumption
  • Quantum Serverless: Beta deployment for scaled pattern execution
  • AI Integration: Automated code development via watsonx and enhanced transpiler tools

Vision: Extended roadmap through 2033

Academic and industry partners from University of Tokyo, Argonne National Lab, BasQ, and others showcased utility-scale quantum applications.

This represents tremendous progress toward realizing the full potential of quantum computing!

Context: In response to Jay Gambetta’s post about IBM Quantum Summit 2023 announcements, highlighting hardware and software advances toward quantum utility.

Qiskit: An Open-source Framework for Quantum Computing
